Chitosan-derived NC support zirconia as highly efficient catalyst for the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol Xueting Zhu Investigation Formal analysis a Zonghui Liu Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Formal analysis Conceptualization a ⁎ Zhun Hu Validation b Bing Yan Validation a Bing Xue Supervision a ⁎ a Jiangsu Province Engineering Research Center of Biodegradable Materials, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213164, China Jiangsu Province Engineering Research Center of Biodegradable Materials, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University Changzhou Jiangsu 213164 China Jiangsu Province Engineering Research Center of Biodegradable Materials, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou 213164, Jiangsu, China b Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710049, China Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi’an Jiaotong University Xi’an Shaanxi 710049 China Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, Shaanxi, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Developing green and efficient catalysts for converting biomass into high-value chemicals is of great significance in heterogeneous catalysis. Herein, we prepared a series of wZrO2/NC_T with various ZrO2 loading (w) and pyrolysis temperature (T) by a hydrothermal carbonization-pyrolysis method using green and inexpensive bio-chitosan as nitrogen-doped carbon materials (NC) precursor, and applied to the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of furfural (FUR) to furfuryl alcohol (FAL). A 99.7 % FUR conversion and 96.5 % FAL selectivity was achieved over 33ZrO2/NC_750 catalyst using 2-propanol as the hydrogen source under certain reaction conditions, which was much higher than that of ZrO2 and ZrO2/C catalyst. The nitrogen species in NC can not only enhance the dispersion of ZrO2, but also provide a certain amount of Lewis base sites. The synergistic interaction of Lewis acid sites (Zr4 +) and Lewis base sites (N species and O2-) played important roles in the FUR to FAL reaction. Moreover, the absence of Brønsted acid sites reduced the occurrence of side reactions and thereby enhances the selectivity of FAL. The influence of acidic (benzoic acid) and basic (pyridine) additives on the catalytic performance further verified the synergistic acid-base catalytic mechanism. In addition, this catalyst can also catalyze other aldehydes to corresponding alcohols and was reused at least five times without any significant loss of catalytic active and selectivity. Graphical Abstract Keywords Furfural Furfuryl alcohol Catalytic transfer hydrogenation ZrO2/NC Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass, as a sustainable source of natural carbon to replace fossil fuels in the production of high value-added products, has attracted widespread attention. Furfural (FUR) is a key platform compound that can be cheaply produced through the catalytic conversion of C5 carbohydrates from hemicellulose biomass [1–3]. As a bio-based platform compound containing both aldehydic functional group and 5-membered monocyclic heteroarene furan ring, FUR can convert to many value-added products such as furfuryl alcohol (FAL), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol, levulinic acid, 2-methylfuran, γ-valerolactone and other fine chemicals [4–10]. As the primary industrial derivative of FUR, FAL constitutes approximately 65 % of its annual global production [11]. This key chemical intermediate is widely used in the manufacturing process, especially in the production of agricultural pesticides, polymer materials and phenolic resins, as well as for other industrial applications [12]. The catalytic hydrogenation pathways for converting FUR to FAL mainly include direct hydrogenation and catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH). In conventional direct hydrogenation processes, the use of H2 as the primary hydrogen source presents some challenges, such as the inherent safety concerns associated with high-pressure H2, and thermodynamic propensity for over-hydrogenation side reactions that decrease FAL selectivity. Notably, direct hydrogenation often uses precious metals such as Pt [13,14], Au [15], Pd [16–19]and Ru[20,21] as catalysts, which will further increase the production cost. Emerging as a promising alternative, CTH strategies employ liquid-phase hydrogen donors, primarily categorized into acid-mediated and alcohol-based systems. While acidic hydrogen donors (usually formic acid[22–24]) demonstrate effective proton transfer capabilities, their practical application is constrained by accelerated reactor corrosion under prolonged operational conditions. In contrast, alcohol donors exhibit enhanced process sustainability due to its safety and high efficiency. Extensive research has confirmed that the synergistic interaction of Lewis acid sites (LAS) and Lewis base sites (LBS) serves as critical active centers in the transfer hydrogenation systems, which has prompted researcher to develop bifunctional catalysts suitable for this reaction. To date, a diverse array of catalysts has been developed and successfully implemented in this CTH of FUR to FAL reaction, including Zr-based [25–28], Ni-based [29–31], Ru-based [32,33], Cu-based [34–37], Al-based [38–40], etc. Very recently, Tian et al. [5] synthesized high-entropy HE-UiO-66 catalysts for the CTH of FUR to FAL reaction. The catalytic performance exhibits a positive correlation with configurational entropy in UiO-66 systems. When the number of metals increased from single metal Zr to five metals ZrHfCeSnTi, the yield of FAL gradually increased and reached the highest value of 80.6 % in HE-UiO-66. This enhancement of performance primarily originates from entropy-driven strategy, which effectively generated a high density of unsaturated metal coordination sites. Extensive studies have demonstrated that nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) materials exhibit extensive applications in heterogeneous catalysis owing to their structural tunability and electronic modifiability. Firstly, the introduction of nitrogen to carbon materials can effectively regulate the acid-base properties of the catalyst and improve its activation ability for reactant molecules[28,41]. Secondly, the synergistic coordination between nitrogen and catalytic active centers (e.g., metals or metal oxides) establishes strong metal-support interactions, thereby enhancing the dispersion and stability of active site and improving the catalytic performance [19,42–44]. It is known that the pyridinic nitrogen in NC materials exhibits non-hybridized lone-pair electrons, demonstrating pronounced electron-donating capabilities that serve as LBS, thereby promoting the progress of CTH reaction. However, the use of NC as supporting for the CTH of FUR to FAL reaction has not been reported. In this work, a series of ZrO2/NC catalysts with different ZrO2 loading were prepared by a hydrothermal carbonization-pyrolysis method using green and inexpensive bio-chitosan as NC precursor ( Scheme 1). Under optimum reaction conditions (150 °C, 2 h,100 mg catalyst, in 2-propanol), A 92.9 % FUR conversion with 96.4 % FAL selectivity was obtained over 33ZrO2/NC_750 catalyst. The excellent catalytic performance is primarily attributed to the synergistic catalytic effect between the LAS and LBS in the catalyst. Meanwhile, the absence of Brønsted acid sites in this catalyst effectively avoids the occurrence of side reactions. The effect of acidic additives (benzoic acid) and basic additives (pyridine) on the catalytic performance further verified the synergistic catalytic mechanism of LAS and LBS. In addition, this catalyst has also showed excellent catalytic stability and universality. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalyst was synthesized through hydrothermal carbonization followed by high-temperature pyrolysis (Scheme 1). First, 1.5 g chitosan was dissolved in 5 wt% acetic acid solution (50 mL). a certain amount of ZrOCl2·8H₂O was then mixed in the above solution under continuous stirring at room temperature. The mixture solution was transferred to a hydrothermal autoclave and carbonized at 180 °C for 8 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained black solid-liquid mixture was dried overnight in an oven at 100 °C. The solid power was finally calcined at specified temperature for 2 h in a tube furnace under N₂ atmosphere with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. The final catalyst was designated as wZrO₂/NC_T, where w and T represents the mass loading of Zr and the calcination temperature. Unless otherwise specified, the calcination temperature of the catalyst is 750 °C. 2.2 Catalyst characterization To investigate the structural and surface characteristics of the synthesized catalysts, a series of characterization were investigated. The textural properties were evaluated through N2 adsorption-desorption, while crystallographic features were analyzed using powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). Morphological and chemical attributes were examined via high-resolution electron microscopy techniques (SEM/TEM) coupled with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. Acidic profiles were quantified through ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), with Brønsted/Lewis acid differentiation achieved via pyridine-probed infrared spectroscopy (Py-FTIR). The actual Zr loading was determined by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). Standard characterization procedures and instrumental configurations are documented in the Supplementary Materials. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The CTH reaction of FUR with 2-propanol was performed in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave. In a typical catalytic reaction, 100 mg of catalyst, 2 mmol of FUR and 10 mL of solvent were transferred into the autoclave. The autoclave was then sealed, purged with N2, and heated to the reaction temperature. After the reaction, the reactor was quickly cooled to room temperature. Finally, the mixture solution was filtered and analyzed by gas chromatograph (GC). The conversion of FUR and selectivity of FAL were calculated by the following equations: FUR conversion % = moles of FUR reacted moles of FUR in the feed × 100 % FAL selectivity % = moles of FAL in the product moles of FUR reacted × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Figs. 1 a and b present the XRD patterns of 48ZrO2/NC_T samples pyrolyzed at different temperatures and wZrO2/NC_750 samples with varying Zr loadings, respectively. Fig. 1 a reveals that all samples exhibited distinct diffraction peaks corresponding to ZrO2, with no detectable impurity phases. At pyrolysis temperatures below 600 °C, only a single crystalline phase of tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2, PDF No. 49–1642) is observed, characterized by peaks at 2θ = 30.1°, 34.9°, 50.2°, 59.7°, 62.6°, and 73.9°. However, increasing the pyrolysis temperature leads to the emergence of three additional peaks at 2θ = 24.5°, 28.2°, and 31.4° attributed to monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2, PDF No. 72–1669). Furthermore, tetragonal ZrO2 remains the predominant phase when the Zr loading is below 33 % (Fig. 1 b). The FTIR of wZrO2/NC_750 also confirmed the successful loading of ZrO2 on the NC support, and when the loading amount of Zr increased to 44 %, a tetragonal phase of ZrO2 was observed (Figure S1). Additionally, a diffraction peaks at 2θ = 26.5° related to carbon nitride (CN) are detectable in samples with Zr loadings below 22 %. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of wZrO2/NC_750 samples were shown in Figure S2, a type I isotherm was observed, indicating that ZrO2/NC_750 contain micropore. As the Zr loading increased from 22 % to 48 %, the surface area and pore volume decreased from 294 to 94 m2/g and from 0.15 to 0.06 m3/g, respectively. In addition, the pore size (0.5–0.6 nm) remained almost unchanged (Table S1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the catalysts was conducted in air (Figure S3). The TGA curves indicated a significant mass loss as the samples were heated from room temperature to 800 °C. An initial minor mass loss (< 8 wt%) occurring below 150 °C was ascribed to physisorbed water. On the NC support, more than 90 % of the weight loss was observed, which was attributed to the combustion of the NC material. In contrast, there was no mass lose of ZrO2 when the temperature increased to 800 °C. When Zr was supported on NC materials, the mass loss is mainly attributed to the combustion of the NC material. Furthermore, increasing the ZrO2 loading led to a decrease in catalyst mass loss. The morphology of NC support and 33ZrO2/NC_750 was characterized by SEM and TEM. In the NC sample, a smooth sheet-like structure was observed with a sparse distribution of nanoscale pores on the surface ( Fig. 2 a). After loading ZrO2, numerous nano-ZrO2 particles appeared on the NC support (Fig. 2 b). TEM image confirmed the uniform distribution of ZrO2 particles on NC and the average particle size of ZrO2 was about 3.5 nm (Fig. 2 c). The high-resolution TEM exhibited lattice fringes of 0.296 nm and 0.284 nm, which matched with the (111) plane of t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2, respectively (Fig. 2 d). In addition, The EDS mapping image of 33ZrO2/NC_750 showed homogeneous dispersion of C, N, Zr and O (Fig. 2 e). The elemental composition and chemical environment of the ZrO2/NC catalyst were analyzed by XPS spectroscopy. The survey spectra ( Fig. 3 a) confirmed the presence of O (531 eV), N (399 eV), C (284 eV) and Zr (182 eV) in ZrO2/NC catalyst. High-resolution spectra of the Zr 3d, O 1 s and N 1 s region were further analyzed to determine their chemical states. The Zr 3d spectra exhibited two signals from 181 eV to 184 eV and from 184 eV to 187 eV, respectively attributed to the Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 electron orbitals (Fig. 3 b). Compared to pure ZrO2, the position of these two peaks shifted to the lower binding energies after ZrO2 was supported on NC. This shift provides evidence for the chemical bonding of ZrO2 to the NC support, probably due to the interaction between Zr and N of NC. Moreover, the blue shift observed in the Zr 3d spectra indicated an increase in the density of positive charges Zr atoms in ZrO2/NC, leading to a decrease in Lewis acidity. The O 1 s spectra can be fitted into tree peaks (Fig. 3 c)[45,46]. For ZrO2, the primary peaks at 530.6 eV represented the lattice oxygen (OI) of ZrO2, while the peaks at 532.1 and 533.2 eV corresponded to surface defect oxygen (OII) and surface chemisorbed oxygen (OIII), respectively. Similar to Zr 3d, the O 1 s binding energy of ZrO2/NC also exhibited a negative shift relative to pure ZrO2. This shift indicates increased negative charge density on oxygen atoms and enhanced Lewis basicity in the ZrO2/NC catalyst. It is known that in the CTH reaction, LAS facilitate hydrogen transfer while LBS activate hydroxyl groups through nucleophilic interactions, forming a cooperative catalytic mechanism. Consistent with prior studies on NC materials[42,47,48], the spectra of N 1 s could be deconvoluted into four peaks (Fig. 3 d). The peak with the lowest binding energy of 398.4 eV corresponded to pyridinic N. Peaks at 400.1 eV and 400.8 eV were assigned to pyrrolic and graphitic N, respectively. The peak located at highest binding energy of 403.2 eV was attributed to pyridinic oxides. These N species are beneficial for the stabilization and dispersion of ZrO2, and also provide basic sites, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of the CTH reaction. It is well known that the acidic and basic sites of the catalyst play a crucial role in the CTH reaction[26,49,50], thus, the acid-base characteristics of the 33ZrO2/NC_750 were characterized using temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) and carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) ( Fig. 4). To circumvent potential interference from water desorption, the NH3-TPD profiles were specifically acquired by monitoring the m/z = 15. For CO2-TPD, the desorption behavior was tracked via the molecular CO2 signal at m/z = 44. The NH3-TPD profile exhibited two distinct broad desorption peaks at 213 and 264 °C (Fig. 4 a), corresponding to the weak and medium acid sites, respectively, with acid densities of 0.15 and 0.16 mmol NH3 gcatal. –1. For CO2-TPD profile (Fig. 4 b), the desorption of CO2 started at 100 °C and peaked at 295 °C, indicating that weak bases and moderately strong bases sites were mainly present in the ZrO2/NC catalyst. The basic sites of NC are mainly provided by uncondensed amino group, such as –NH2 and –NH[51,52]. Additionally, a small CO2 desorption peak was also observed at 167 °C, which is attributed to the weak basic site. Furthermore, the number of basic sites is 0.78 mmol CO2 gcatal. –1, significantly higher than the number of acidic sites (0.31 mmol NH3 gcatal. –1) in ZrO2/NC. Given the critical role of acidic site type in CTH reaction, pyridine-adsorption FTIR spectroscopy (Py-FTIR) was employed to characterize the prepared catalysts as shown in Fig. 5. Characteristic bands for LAS were identified at 1447, 1580, and 1600 cm⁻¹ , while BAS exhibited a peak at 1540 cm⁻¹ . The band at 1490 cm⁻¹ corresponds to pyridine adsorbed on both LAS and BAS[7,53–55]. It is clear seen that all the catalysts exhibited adsorption band related with the LAS, which are caused by pyridine adsorption on surface Zr4 +. Moreover, the density of these peaks decreased with increasing the adsorption temperature. This is because as the temperature increase, pyridine gradually desorbed from the acidic sites. In contrast, no adsorption peaks related with BAS were detected in all samples even at low evacuation temperature. Combined with the following catalytic results, it can be concluded that the active sites in the CTH reaction is LAS rather than BAS. Furthermore, the intensity of LAS increased with the higher ZrO2 loading, but it is lower than that of pure ZrO2, this result was also consistent with the XPS results (Fig. 3 b). 3.2 Catalytic performance for the CTH of FUR to FAL reaction 3.2.1 Activity evaluation of different catalysts It is well known that the pyrolysis temperature has a significant effect on the properties of carbon materials, which in turn affects the catalytic performance of the catalyst[56]. Therefore, we first studied the influence of different pyrolysis temperatures on the catalytic performance of 48ZrO2/NC_T using 2-propanol as the hydrogen donor and solvent. As shown in Fig. 6, the selectivity of FAL exhibited a steady increase from 21.3 % to 88.4 % with increasing pyrolysis temperature from 500 °C to 700 °C. Upon further elevating the temperature to 800 °C, the selectivity initially demonstrated a gradual increase to 92.4 % (750 °C), followed by a decline to 86.6 % (800 °C). Concurrently, FUR conversion displayed a parabolic trend across the 500–800 °C temperature range and attaining its maximum value (79.9 %) at 750 °C. Therefore, the optimal pyrolysis temperature is 750 °C. The catalytic performance of wZrO2/NC with varying Zr loading was subsequently evaluated and the results were shown in Table 1. In the blank experiment, only a 2.2 % FUR conversion was observed (Entry 1), indicating that the CTH reaction of FUR to FAL is hard to occur without catalyst. For comparison, both NC support and ZrO2 as the catalyst were also applied in this reaction. The NC support showed a 4.3 % FUR conversion and 87.5 % FUR selectivity (Entry 2), while ZrO2 also exhibited limited catalytic efficiency with 29.9 % conversion and 78.8 % selectivity toward FAL (Entry 3). The catalytic behavior exhibited a clear dependence on the loading of Zirconium (Entry 4–9). At 9 wt% Zr loading on the NC support, the FUR conversion (30.5 %) and FAL selectivity (77.6 %) remained comparable to those of pure ZrO2. Interestingly, increasing the Zr loading to 33 wt% induced a progressive enhancement in catalytic performance, achieving 99.7 % FUR conversion and 96.5 % FAL selectivity. The improvement of catalytic performance might be caused by the synergistic effect of LAS (Zr4+) and LBS (O2- of ZrO2 and N species of NC). However, further increasing the loading to 48 wt% resulted in a notable decline in FUR conversion (79.9 %), this may be due to a reduction in surface area caused by Zirconia agglomeration. The observed volcanic activity pattern suggests an optimal balance between LAS/LBS density (enhanced by moderate ZrO2 loading) and mass transfer efficiency (pore blockage caused by excessive load). In order to verify the role of N species (LBS) in the reaction, we also synthesized the 33ZrO2/C catalyst using active carbon as the support (Entry 10). A decreased in FUR conversion (66.5 %) was observed, suggesting that N species of ZrO2/NC was important for this reaction. In addition, to further investigate the influence of acid-base sites on the CTH reaction, we conducted selective poisoning experiments by introducing 2 mmol of pyridine (adsorbed on the acid site) or benzoic acid (adsorbed on the basic site) into the reactor prior to catalytic testing using the 33ZrO2/NC catalyst. To more clearly observe the effect of these additives on catalytic activity (in case the conversion increase), the FUR conversion was decreased by lowing the reaction temperature to 150 °C and the time to 2 h. The results from Fig. 7 showed that the control experiment (without adding any additives) achieved 92.9 % FUR conversion with 96.4 % FAL selectivity. The introduction of pyridine resulted in a slight decline in FUR conversion (83.2 %), indicating that LAS are beneficial for the CTH reactions. Strikingly, benzoic acid addition caused a dramatic reduction in FUR conversion to 9.5 %, strongly demonstrating that basic sites are crucial for facilitating the CTH process. Selective site-poisoning studies demonstrated that dual acid-base functionality is essential for converting FUR to FAL reaction. 3.2.2 The effect of reaction parameters The catalytic performance of 33ZrO2/NC was systematically evaluated under varying reaction conditions, with critical parameters such as temperature (120–160 °C), duration (1–6 h), hydrogen donor (alcohol, C1-C4), and catalyst amount (10–120 mg) being optimized ( Fig. 8). As shown in Fig. 8 a, when reaction temperature increased from 120 °C to 150 °C, the conversion of FUR increased from 57.1 % to 92.9 %. Further increasing the temperature to 160 °C had little effect on FUR conversion. Similarly, the selectivity of FAL followed a similar trend, increasing from 83.8 % at 120 °C to 96.8 % at 140 °C, and then remaining almost unchanged. Considering both FUR conversion and FAL selectivity, the optimal reaction temperature is 150 °C. The effect of reaction time on the CTH reaction at the optimal temperature of 150 °C is shown in Fig. 8 b. It can be seen that the FUR conversion reached 93 % after 2 h and subsequently showed gradual enhancement to 99.7 % upon extending the reaction duration to 6 h. Notably, FAL selectivity maintained consistently superior performance above 90 % throughout the time course. Fig. 8 c illustrate that the catalyst amount exhibited a similar effect as the reaction time. When increasing the catalyst amount from 10 mg to 100 mg, significant improvements were observed with FUR conversion improving from 22.3 % to 92.9 % and FAL selectivity increasing from 16.3 % to 96.4 %. Further increasing the catalyst amount did not significantly change the catalytic performance. Therefore, the optimal catalyst amount is 100 mg. The effect of hydrogen donor on catalytic performance were finally studied on 33ZrO2/NC catalyst under the optimum conditions (150 °C, 2 h and 100 mg catalyst). As shown in Fig. 8 d, both carbon chain length (C1-C4) and alcohol type (primary or secondary) have a significant influence on FUR conversion and FAL selectivity. Notable, all the used alcohols except methanol demonstrated effective catalytic activity for the FUR to FAL reaction. When methanol was used as the hydrogen and solvent, a high FUR conversion of 73.4 % was achieved, but the FAL selectivity was only 0.9 %. This is mainly due to the competitive acetalization between FUR and methanol, the similar results were also observed in the same reaction using other catalysts[5,39,57]. Particularly, the primary alcohols (methanol, ethanol, n-propanol and 1-butanol) presented a much lower FUR conversion (<75 %) and FAL selectivity (<50 %) than secondary alcohols. It is because the primary alcohols have higher reduction potential than secondary alcohols. In the comparison of secondary alcohols, although the selectivity of FAL was similar, the FUR conversion in 2-butanol was slightly lower (79.7 %) than that in 2-propanol (92.9 %). This difference is due to the steric effect caused by the longer carbon chain in 2-butanol. Therefor, 2-propanol proved to be the most effective hydrogen donor for the CTH reaction. For comparison, the catalytic performance of various previously reported catalysts (e.g., Zr-, Cu-, Fe-, Co-, and Al-based materials) for the CTH of FUR to FAL reaction was listed in Table 2. It can be seen that most catalysts were carried out at higher reaction temperature and longer reaction time to obtain a higher FUR conversion, and the ZrO2/NC catalyst exhibited a superior performance under milder conditions. Moreover, the ZrO2/NC catalyst was synthesized by a simple hydrothermal carbonization-pyrolysis method using chitosan as the NC precursor, which is more convenient than the preparation methods of other catalysts listed in Table 2. Given its favorable catalytic efficiency and simplified synthesis, ZrO2/NC demonstrates promising potential for the CTH of FUR to FAL. 3.2.3 Reusability and universality of the catalyst The reusability of 33ZrO2/NC was evaluated under optimum reaction conditions (150 °C, 2 h,100 mg catalyst, in 2-propanol) for the FAL production from FUR. Prior to the next reaction, the used catalyst was separated by filtration and washed 3 times with ethanol to thoroughly remove any organic residues adsorbed on catalyst, and finally dried at 110 °C for 12 h. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the 33ZrO₂/NC catalyst demonstrated remarkable stability with sustained FUR conversion (>93 %) and FAL selectivity (>91 %) over five consecutive cycles. To further verify the heterogeneous nature of the catalyst, the catalyst was removed when the reaction reached 0.5 h (with a FUR conversion of 69 %) (Fig. 9 b). The filtrate was then reacted for 2 h and 4 h under the same conditions. The results showed that FUR conversion was almost unchanged, confirming that the active site did not dissolve into the reaction solution. Cyclic usage and thermal filtration experiments demonstrated that 33ZrO₂/NC exhibits high efficiency and durability in the CTH of FUR. The excellent stability might be attributed to the strong anchoring effect of NC on the metal oxides. The CTH reaction of different aldehydes to the corresponding alcohols were also investigated over 33ZrO2/NC catalyst. As shown in Table 3, the catalyst presented excellent catalytic performance with both aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes. For salicylaldehyde (Substrate 1), a moderate conversion of 51.6 % was achieved with exceptionally high selectivity (99.2 %), suggesting that salicylaldehyde was more difficult to active and may require a higher temperature or longer reaction time to obtain the higher conversion. Notably, very high conversion of benzaldehyde (93.2 %) and selectivity of benzyl alcohol (99.2 %) was obtained over this catalyst. Moreover, excellent catalytic efficiency has also been achieved for para-substituted aromatic aldehydes: p-methoxybenzaldehyde (Substrate 2: 97.9 % conversion, 96.9 % selectivity), and p-methylbenzaldehyde (Substrate 4: 99.5 % conversion, 98.1 % selectivity). Furthermore, the catalyst demonstrated high activity in aliphatic alcohol, achieving 86.3 % conversion of pentanal (Substrate 5) with 84.1 % selectivity toward pentanol. These results demonstrate that the prepared ZrO2/NC has good universality for the CTH reaction of different aldehydes to the corresponding alcohols. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of catalysts based on nitrogen-doped carbon materials (wZrO2/NC_T) with abundant LAS and LBS were synthesized using hydrothermal carbonization-pyrolysis of chitosan method and applied to the CTH of FUR to FAL reaction. The conversion of FUR first increases and then decreases with the increase of ZrO2 loading (w=9–48 wt%) and the rise of pyrolysis temperature (T = 500–800 °C). The 33ZrO2/NC_750 catalyst was identified as the most efficient catalyst, providing a 92.9 % FUR conversion and 96.4 % FAL selectivity at 150 °C for 2 h. Moreover, this catalyst can be reused at least 5 times without losing its catalytic activity. Correlating the catalytic performance with characterization results revealed that the synergistic interaction of LAS and LBS plays a crucial role in the FUR to FAL reaction. The addition of benzoic acid and pyridine to the reaction system decreased the FUR conversion, indicating that both acid sites and basic site are crucial for the CTH reaction. In addition, their wide applicability to various aldehydes enhances their flexibility, and they are expected to become important catalysts in industrial fields. coredata.dc:description: Developing green and efficient catalysts for converting biomass into high-value chemicals is of great significance in heterogeneous catalysis. Herein, we prepared a series of wZrO2/NC_T with various ZrO2 loading (w) and pyrolysis temperature (T) by a hydrothermal carbonization-pyrolysis method using green and inexpensive bio-chitosan as nitrogen-doped carbon materials (NC) precursor, and applied to the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of furfural (FUR) to furfuryl alcohol (FAL). A 99.7 % FUR conversion and 96.5 % FAL selectivity was achieved over 33ZrO2/NC_750 catalyst using 2-propanol as the hydrogen source under certain reaction conditions, which was much higher than that of ZrO2 and ZrO2/C catalyst. The nitrogen species in NC can not only enhance the dispersion of ZrO2, but also provide a certain amount of Lewis base sites. The synergistic interaction of Lewis acid sites (Zr4 +) and Lewis base sites (N species and O2-) played important roles in the FUR to FAL reaction. Moreover, the absence of Brønsted acid sites reduced the occurrence of side reactions and thereby enhances the selectivity of FAL. The influence of acidic (benzoic acid) and basic (pyridine) additives on the catalytic performance further verified the synergistic acid-base catalytic mechanism. In addition, this catalyst can also catalyze other aldehydes to corresponding alcohols and was reused at least five times without any significant loss of catalytic active and selectivity.
